doc.field: He had never been that blunt before, but today Russian president Yeltsin took the cake when speaking out against NATO's airstrikes. In case Yugoslavia got invaded by ground-troops and the invaders set up a 'protectorate' there, Russia would intervene, according to agency reports. Mr Yeltsin said on television that he had warned NATO, the Americans and the Germans that there could be a European or even World War if his country got dragged into the conflict. The US, however, stated that high-ranking Moscow officials had reassured them once again on Friday afternoon, that they would not intervene. Meanwhile NATO spokesperson Shea told Russia that NATO did not plan an invasion of the Kosovo.

Airstrikes kept going, also during orthodox Good Friday, and in the evening sirens sounded again in Belgrade. Several hundred people gathered on the main bridge over the river Save, to protect it against airstrikes ('human shields'). According to Belgrade, fuel depots, factories and TV-stations were hit last Friday night, and there had been casualties in industrial areas.

Last Thursday a bomb hit a residential area in the provincial capital of Pristina, according to NATO. Airforce Commander Wilby stated that the precision device had been deflected and therefore had hit houses some 200 to 300 metres from the intended target (the central telephone exchange). He said he was sorry, though there was no way NATO could be responsible for all the damage caused in Pristina's residential areas, as Serb leaders claimed.
Till Monday some 5000 refugees will have reached Germany

This weekend more rescue-flights, organised by the federal German government, will take place to help a total of 10,000 refugees. Till the beginning of next week some 5000 refugees, that's half of the total targetted, should have touched down at German airports. Last Friday approximately 600 refugees were flown from Skopje to Germany.
Chancellor Schroeder adamant there will be no ground-troops

Chancellor Schroeder once again declined to send ground-troops to the Balkan. In a recent interview on television he stated that government saw no reason why they should change their current strategy, and that was it. Defence Minister Scharping and Foreign Minister Fischer agreed. General Naumann, head of the German NATO military committee, said that sending ground-troops still was a theoretical option. Politicians would have to decide on that, after evaluating the situation.
Number of applicants for asylum stable in spite of Kosovo conflict

The Kosovo conflict so far has not done anything to the numbers of persons applying for asylum in Germany, according to Federal Minister for Internal Affairs Schily. Numbers were 2736, that's 8.6% up on last month - 84% of them calling themselves Kosovo-Albanians - but the numbers had been stable until the end of March. The total number of applicants had risen by 8.1% compared to February. There will be 2000 more refugees from the Kosovo till Saturday.
14-million mark study halted by Minister Trittin

Federal Environment Minister Trittin has halted work on a 14-million mark study about nuclear power-plants using pressurised water for cooling. He said that there was no need for this project any more, as nuclear power generation was on its way out in Germany. The paper was meant to develop safety requirements for future nuclear power-plants. Since 1989 both France and Germany had been involved in the project.
